Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\) where x and y are functions of time, t, subject to a linear transformation \\( T(z) = Az + B \\) with constant matrices A and B. The function z evolves according to the differential equation \\( \\dot{z} = Cz \\) where C is another constant matrix.

If the transformation \\( T(z) \\) is applied to \\( z_0 \\) at t = 0 and the resultant function is allowed to evolve under \\( \\dot{z} = Cz \\) without further intervention, will the state of \\( z(T) \\) for T > 0 be the same as if \\( z_0 \\) was directly evolved under \\( \\dot{z} = Cz \\)?
Explanation: The transformation \\( T(z) \\) modifies the initial condition to \\( Az_0 + B \\). Thus, the trajectory of z will evolve from this new initial condition under \\( \\dot{z} = Cz \\), leading to a different state at any time T compared to direct evolution from \\( z_0 \\).
